canvases.label: The witty and entertaining exploits of George Buchanan, Title page

metadata.value: The witty and entertaining exploits of George Buchanan
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: The Witty and Entertaining Exploits of George Buchanan, who was Commonly called the King's Fool The Whole Sis [sic] Parts Complete. To Which is Added Witty and Entertaining Jests, &c.
metadata.label: Variant Title

metadata.value: Title page from a popular Scottish chapbook, which was reprinted many times throughout the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. This edition was printed and sold in Niddery's Wynd (Edinburgh). The title page contains a spelling error: six is printed as "sis". The sixth edition contains "Added Witty and Entertaining Jests, &c" not included in earlier editions. The page displays a woodcut image of a man. Above the printer's information at the bottom of the page, "[Edinburgh]" as the place of publication has been written in ink by hand. The currently undigitised artefact that this page comes from is an interesting volume. Interleaved with the 1781 pages are manuscript pages and illustrations from c. 1822. Numbers referencing annotations and notes have been written into the original pages, including numbers for notes which the new editor never completed. This hybrid edition/manuscript contains a handwritten page that states: “’One Hundred Years hence’ to be published, by the then Secretary of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, - a new and improved edition, of The Witty Exploits of George Buchanan; with suitable illustrations from the most famous pews of this critical and imaginative Age; and adorned with elegant engravings from original drawings by distinguished Artists. The mentioned illustrations are by Alexander Corse and Alexander Christie and are distributed throughout the volume. No full name is given of the new editor, but the secretary of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland from 1819-1822 was John Dillon, so it is possible that he is the editor. David Laing was also a long-standing member of this Society, possibly indicating where he came to acquire this book.
